block.p: The Senate voted to approve a $7.8 billion project intended to restore the Everglades and its ailing ecosystem, a plan supporters called the most ambitious environmental restoration effort ever undertaken. The Everglades has been dying since 1948, when the Army Corps of Engineers rerouted its water flow. Fixing the problem would take 40 years, and Florida would pay half the cost. But the legislation must pass the House, where its prospects are uncertain.

The Senate voted to approve a $7.8 billion project intended to restore the Everglades and its ailing ecosystem, a plan supporters called the most ambitious environmental restoration effort ever undertaken. The Everglades has been dying since 1948, when the Army Corps of Engineers rerouted its water flow. Fixing the problem would take 40 years, and Florida would pay half the cost. But the legislation must pass the House, where its prospects are uncertain.
